meaning_mnemonic: "A <radical>scooter</radical>!" you <radical>announce</radical>. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would <kanji>create</kanji>.

There are <radical>fingers</radical> reaching towards you asking you to <radical>accept</radical> to <kanji>instruct</kanji> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!

You take this <radical>comb</radical>, break the handle off, and use it to <radical>stamp</radical> your official <kanji>seal</kanji> of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy <kanji>mark</kanji>ing process, but it gets the job done.

In your <radical>warehouse</radical> you use your <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>create</kanji>. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.

You <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>black hole</radical>, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to <kanji>restore</kanji> mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.

You <radical>loiter</radical> around your <radical>master</radical> until he <kanji>depart</kanji>s on a <kanji>journey</kanji>. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.

Your new <radical>car</radical> doesn’t <radical>mix</radical> well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark <kanji>contrast</kanji> to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.

Out of <radical>bamboo</radical>, you make a <radical>brush</radical> – a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!

You hold <radical>gold</radical> <radical>fins</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> while shopping for pencil <kanji>lead</kanji> at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.

You keep all of your <radical>shellfish</radical> under a <radical>roof</radical> down the <radical>street</radical> and it's your <kanji>savings</kanji>. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
The <radical>old</radical> <radical>winter</radical> is to blame for today's <kanji>circumstance</kanji>. It is the <kanji>reason</kanji> things are bad now.

There's a <radical>building</radical> standing in the way of the next <radical>chapter</radical> in your life, and it's <kanji>hinder</kanji>ing you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.
If you see someone <radical>loiter</radical>ing around with <radical>horns</radical> on their head you'd be <radical>correct</radical> to <kanji>obey</kanji> and <kanji>accompany</kanji> them.

Your <radical>ego</radical>... it's totally out of control. <kanji>I</kanji> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <kanji>me</kanji>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.

A <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical>, traveling in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji> force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
The "<radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Ten Thousand</radical> <radical>Power</radical>" is where you go if you want to be <kanji>encourage</kanji>d.

They <radical>say</radical> using a <radical>measurement</radical> device (like a ruler) is a good way to <kanji>chastise</kanji> someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!

A broken <radical>car</radical> sits in a <radical>building</radical>. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the <kanji>mail</kanji>. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the <kanji>post</kanji>.

In a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>cross</radical>, you see a <kanji>needle</kanji> sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
A <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> is an <kanji>indication</kanji> or <kanji>sign</kanji> of something to come.

You see a <radical>soul</radical> floating around a <radical>tombstone</radical> acting <kanji>suspicious</kanji>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.

On the <radical>grass</radical> near a <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits a <radical>creeper</radical> that is some sort of a <radical>dog</radical> <kanji>beast</kanji>, a vicious <kanji>animal</kanji>. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.

You take some <radical>flowers</radical> and some <radical>fruit</radical> and you make a <kanji>cake</kanji> out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.

During a <radical>tsunami</radical>, your <radical>lip ring</radical> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <kanji>river</kanji>. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.

You're trying to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cause a <radical>landslide</radical> so you have to <kanji>shake</kanji> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <kanji>wave</kanji> at the ground now.
The <radical>tsunami</radical> going down your <radical>dry</radical> face is just <kanji>sweat</kanji>.

Under the <radical>ground</radical>, a <radical>head</radical> covered in <radical>dirt</radical> emerges... <kanji>again</kanji>! It's not the first time you've seen this buried head, nor is it the last. This dirt-covered head hides beneath the ground wherever you go, and keeps popping up to scare you again and again.
Your <radical>fingers</radical> touch as you <radical>stand</radical> with a <radical>woman</radical> and <kanji>adjoin</kanji> yourselves. You are united, you are one.

There once was an <radical>animal</radical> with an <radical>insect</radical> friend who felt very <kanji>alone</kanji> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.

The  <radical>fortune</radical> radical and the <kanji>fortune</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! This can also mean <kanji>occupy</kanji>, maybe because learning your fortune shows you how you're going to occupy your life. Or how it will occupy you…

You haven't seen the radical in a while, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the kanji: Put your toe in your mouth to learn your <kanji>fortune</kanji>. The taste will tell you everything you need to know about your fortune. But your toe has to <kanji>occupy</kanji> your mouth first for it to work.
This kanji comes straight from the <radical>droopy</radical> radical. What do droopy things do? They <kanji>droop</kanji>. Oh, and sometimes they <kanji>dangle</kanji> too.

You're using your <radical>fingers</radical> to do something important for this <radical>ceremony</radical>'s <radical>construction</radical>. What's really important for this ceremony's construction, using your fingers? Well… you <kanji>wipe</kanji> the floors.

"Take your <radical>fingers</radical>. <radical>Now</radical>, put them on your foe's <radical>heart</radical> and <kanji>twist</kanji>." These are the words of your martial arts master as he teaches you his final, ultimate technique: the "finger-heart twister."

When you hold out your <radical>fingers</radical>, a <radical>person</radical> — and then a second <radical>person</radical> — stomps them into the <radical>dirt</radical>, leaving you with a serious finger <kanji>sprain</kanji>. That wasn't very nice of either person, and now you feel awfully <kanji>discourage</kanji>d about things.
